Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2010 06:09PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Hi JDX.  You don't say your age and that may play a factor.  Also have you had the BC gene mutation test (BRCA 1 2)?  That may give you more information to help in making your decision.  It very much is a game of duck, duck, goose.  I had my first biopsy about 12 years ago which was benign.  But the surgeon at the time said that I would be much more likely to have more lumps in the future.  This time I wasn't so lucky and decided early on for a mastectomy v. lumpectomy.  First I had an excisional biopsy (identical to a lumpectomy).  Path results came back and margins were not clear.  And, no guarantees another lumpectomy would be clear.  Survival rates are identical lump & radiation vs. mastec - but recurrence rate is lower for mastec.  In addition, I did not want radiation and I wanted to be sure the cancer was gone.  I had left mastectomy, no reconstruction 3 weeks ago.  No regrets whatsoever.  Compared to the appendectomy I had in July, this surgery recovery is much easier.  I never needed to take more than a couple of tylenol now & then.  As someone said reconstruction is a whole different ballgame and you need to be committed to more procedures, lengthy recovery time.   Docs assured me I could change my mind in the future about reconstruction - but I doubt it very seriously.  I had the BRCA tests last week and if they come back positive I would not hesitate to have right side mastectomy prophylactically (and not have to deal with another SNB too).   My breast surgeon was great and have only a very thin incision/scar.  Anyway, that's my story.  As everyone has said - weigh all your options, talk to several breast surgeons (the BEST you can find) and you will find the answer that is best for you.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 02:27PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Couple of thoughts.  Good that you are getting a second opinion.  (Get your films and copies of all reports you have so far).  Find the BEST breast surgeon you can (not just a general surgeon) at a major hospital or cancer center.  Discuss the pros/cons of options now and options that you would have down the road if it ever comes back.  I had an excisional biopsy (basically same as lumpectomy) because they couldn't do a needle biopsy in my case.  Margins were not clear.  And there were no guarantees margins would be clear a second time around.  At that point I opted for a mastectomy & no radiation.  Lymph node test (SNB) was done during surgery.  They take a frozen section and results come back while you are still in surgery.  If negative, that's the end of it.  If positive, they take more nodes.  I did not have reconstruction at the same time as mastectomy so that is another whole other discussion to have because there are lots of different methods, coordination w/plastic surgeon, etc.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2010 02:23PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Hi roller girl.  For sure don't wait.   I think napaoctober has good idea - ask your gyn office if they would fax an order for a diagnostic mammogram and skip the office visit until afterwards (or on to a surgeon if you need a biopsy).   They may or may not be able do that without doc seeing you first. (Even if you go to a surgeon, they would likely send you for a screening test next.) The results from the mammogram will determine your next step. Google free mammograms and your city.  If there is a breast cancer center anywhere near you, they are also great - you can be seen by a doctor, get a screening all at the same time.  Anyway, those are some options.  Good luck & God bless.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2011 01:43PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Hi Michelle - no wonder you're tired!  Just rest as much as you can - takes 6-8 weeks to get completely over surgery esp w/general anesthesia and you've been through two already.   I had two mastectomies but no recon.  I would have had the BMX all at the same time but the first time I had just had an appendectomy & lumpectomy where margins weren't clear.  So I had one mastectomy & scheduled the second 6 mos later.  The mastectomies were a lot easier than appendectomy.  I didn't even fill the pain prescription and was pretty much back to normal activities within couple of weeks -- the recovery is gradual however, in terms of getting back full range of arm motion with exercises, etc.  And those first few weeks you will get tired easily.  But you will get back to your old energy levels.  You can't lift anything heavy for a couple of weeks - may be a little longer with reconstruction.  Since there are different reconstruction methods you should be clear about the process, timing, additional surgeries, recovery for each option, how many of these surgeries the PS has done - you want the best breast surgeon & plastic surgeon that you can find.  I'm sure others will be along shortly who have had reconstruction and help you with your question list.  My best to you.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2011 01:14AM JanetinVirginia wrote: Mdg is correct.  There is always a risk of recurrence, but it is less with a mastectomy.  Having said that, survival rates are the same which means if you have lumpec & do have a recurrence, you treat it again.  The thing that bothered me was that mammo didn't catch mine the first time.  And I may not be so lucky the second time (early enough) if I had a recurrence.  So , I opted for mastectomies.  More & more young women who have tested positive for genetic link and have NO breast cancer choose to have prophylactic mastectomies to do everything they can to prevent cancer from starting - they are called 'previvors.'  Sad statement that we haven't come further in terms of prevention.

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2010 06:46AM JanetinVirginia wrote: Hi Ruthlo - you can see the various opinions and you are smart to weigh all your choices.  The most important to me was recurrence rate.  Altho survival rates are the same (5 yrs out) recurrence is lower with mastectomy - less than 1%.  If you have any family history of breast cancer, that is very important too. You might want to take advantage of the genetic test which will tell you if you have the gene mutation. I also wanted to avoid radiation esp. because mine was in left breast & radiation exposure to heart (as well as lungs).  Any surgery with gen'l anesthesia takes time to recover. You'll need plenty of rest either way.  My mastectomy was < two weeks ago (opted no reconstruction).  Recovery has been much better than I thought.  I only had to take regular tylenol now & then.  I had to have my appendix out in July and comparatively speaking, the mastectomy is much easier.   I'm nearly back to normal activity already (no heavy lifting yet).  The process & recovery is longer with reconstruction but is very important to many women.   Good luck with your decision - it's an individual one and you should be totally comfortable with whatever you choose.

It's also a support network especially in small communities.  God bless them all.   The movement accomplished its purpose - to raise awareness.  I have no problem with any of that.   (I do have a problem with flagrant commercialization.)   BUT, where is the ALTERNATIVE?   If there was a viable alternative out there to channel all this energy, attention and money to morph the focus to finding the cause/cure, it would be game-changing.  A million people in Washington DC demanding a breast cancer summit and an overhaul of research & how this country intends to find cause/cure?  I don't care what color they wear.  Remember- we are a HUGE voting block when you think of the millions suffering with cancer and all their relatives!   Maybe we need to start a "Cancer Party" political movement (play on words ie Tea Party).  I don't know - but we need to get to the next step.  To me it's evolutionary.  Pink has a place in that history, but it's way past time for more.

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2010 01:50PM JanetinVirginia wrote: You don't say your age,but here's my advice.  Trust your intuition.  Call the radiologist and ask if they have the results or waiting for previous films.  Then call your doctor's office and ask they request results be faxed to them to speed it up.  (Also get a copy of your report- not the postcard they send the patient - so you have it in your possession.)  I would seriously consider finding another gyn.   And, if you still have doubts about mammo results when you do get them - request an ultrasound.  Different screening techniques have different diagnostic advantages.  And, with family history,you should think about the BRCA genetic test.  Good luck - I hope it turns out to be totally benign!  But you have absolutely done the right thing to insist on the tests.

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2010 07:23PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Deanna - after surgery (excisional biopsy, lumpectomy, mastectomy, etc), pathologists can analyze the mass itself and give you a lot more information than a scan.  The pathology report will you the size of the mass, what kind of cancer it is (if any), the 'grade' of the tumor which tells you how aggressive it is on a scale.  They will also analyze whether the tumor is receptive to hormones, how receptive, and which hormones (that takes a few more days than the first report).  Your 'stage' is usually caculated by those various factors and whether lymph nodes are involved.   What kind of biopsy are you having?  If you are having a needle biopsy, you'll get some of that info, but not all (until the lump is completely removed).

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 09:28AM JanetinVirginia wrote: Hello everyone.  I'm scheduled for a right preventive mastectomy on March 23.  I had left mastectomy in Oct 10.  I would have done a bi-lateral at the time but had just had an emergency appendectomy and an excisional biopsy so I didn't want to push my luck w/anesthesia on 3rd surgery.  I'm doing prophy because I want to reduce recurrence risk & don't want to have to deal with endless screenings/scans, particularly since mammogram never picked up the original cancer! Elmcity - thanks for starting thread!  Are you going to edit your original post to put names/surgery dates?

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2011 09:06AM JanetinVirginia wrote: Chrissy - well if we're supposed to do snow angels at 3 weeks, I'm WAY behind! :)   This is all I know from my L mastec 6 mos ago - and this applies to no reconstruction.  By 4 weeks supposedly internal stitches have healed - the increasing tightness is what you feel when that happens.  Then you get little "zingers" which are the nerves healing.  BS wrote script for physical therapist specializing in mastectomies.  I went twice and the exercises and massages she taught me REALLY helped.  But you don't want to do the massages until 4-5 weeks out.  They release the incision scar so that your skin is flexible and gets back to normal.  For arms, it takes months and months to regain full motion.  Each night when you sleep, you heal more and the muscles etc need to be stretched again the next day until one day you don't feel any pulling anymore.  Until then, need to do the exercises every day. She said many women stop too soon and that's when you run risk of a frozen shoulder, etc.  Next apptmt, ask for script for PT.

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 11:53AM JanetinVirginia wrote: Hi Russia - normally you do not need any radiation after a mastectomy.  It depends on the tumor size and also the margins, or the size of the cancer free area around the tumor.  Doctors want wide margins.  If you tumor is close to the chest wall, radiation may be used.  Chemo generally depends on factors like your stage (size of tumor, whether lymph nodes are involved) & how aggressive the cancer is.  Ask for a copy of your biopsy pathology report and it should have that information on it.

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2010 01:56PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Congrats on having the surgery behind you!  I'm scheduled end of Sept. That's the same thing my surgeon explained - they take one or more nodes and have pathology do a quick analysis while you're still on the table.  If they come back positive, they take more nodes  If negative, they close.   Just to be sure, pathology does a more thorough analysis (slice by slice)of the nodes they tested while you were in surgery.  A small percentage (only about 10%) can show up positive when they do that further testing.  Not totally sure what happens then - maybe they go back in at a later point to take more.  Odds are in your favor.  Good luck.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2010 03:00PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Checking in! East Coast - I think staging of any potential recurrence depends on a number of factors.  It's different if it is a local recurrence v. a distant recurrence so you might ask you onc to give you some peace of mind.  And, you can have a brand new cancer in opposite breast unrelated to the first one which is staged/treated the same as any initial cancer diagnosis.  With a mastectomy, chance of local recurrence is only about 1% (if lumpectomy & rads it is about 5% but I've seen as high as 15%).  That's why I chose mastectomy in the first place and am thinking about a prophy 2nd mastectomy. Yes, well.  I think the psychological healing takes longer than the physical healing.  I'm still trying to get my head around everything that has happened so fast.   I also think it's kind of a delayed reaction - because I was just focused on the surgery & recovery.  Now that it's over (or getting there) the rest of the worries start to creep in esp. with regard to the next round of decision making and all the "what ifs" which can drive you crazy.  And, I believe it will always be in the back of my mind -- all you can do is make informed choices and get back to living.  In that respect, I think there is actually one benefit to being a cancer survivor.  There is a greater appreciation for health and not putting off living & what you want to accomplish in life.  Many, if not most, people just assume they have all the time in the world.  Women have a higher risk of dying from heart disease than breast cancer, for example.  More people are killed in car accidents than by breast cancer.  And, the list goes on.  Just have to try to keep it in perspective - at least that's what I'm telling myself :)

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2010 02:39PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Eileen -  I'm struggling w/same thing only with one side!   I did a little 'retail therapy' today.  Actually wore a bra & the microbead form.  Everything was fine until I started trying on coats. Happened to look in the mirror and I was about 4 inches higher on the microbead side!! :):)  I had to laugh a little.  But I obviously have to find a better solution.  At my follow up yesterday, they gave me a script for prostheses, bras, etc.   If you have a Nordstrom's near you, they have expert fitters.  You could also try Amoena website and see if there is a search capability for your zip code (boutiques, etc.) Surgeon said you need to get fitted for the right bra and the right form - and evidently there are a ton of them to choose from.   In the meantime - go to the party - it will do you good!   You are much more aware than anyone else is going to be! Also nurse told me I was "positive" for cyp2d6 but have no idea if that means I'm positive for the gene mutation that gets in the way of tamoxifen working or if I'm positive for metabolizing it OK.  So I need to ask him that.   Interestingly, this gene also has a negative effect on lots of other prescription medicines - including anti-depressants, some allergy meds, etc.   Going to find out more about that too.  Seems each answer just raises more questions.

Posts.Content: May 9, 2011 04:57PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Hi Chrissy - you describe the "shrinking" sensation perfectly!  And yes - one day it will be normal again. You just have to be religious about the exercises every single day.  As far as my experience, the first time around, at about 4 months, the stretching didn't hurt anymore but definitely still needed stretching.  At about 6 months I just kept the stretches in a regular exercise routine so I wouldn't slip backward in progress -  but didn't do the several times a day anymore.  Both my breast surgeon & physical therapist said on average it takes 6 mos to completely heal from this surgery -- even if you have complete range of motion.  It's all internal with regard to nerves healing, generation of new lymph pathways, tissue, etc.   I believe it this time because of the seroma.  (This new lymph pathway goes on even if no nodes were removed - and none were taken on the prophylactic side I just had done.) She said whether you develop a seroma or not, the body is producing fluid while you heal - most people aren't even aware of it because the body absorbs this excess fluid after drains are removed and some don't - and evidently they don't know why.  I just had another aspiration today and it is almost 7 weeks out!  (I had none of this the first time.)  She has me coming in every 2 weeks to check.  It was down to 25 cc today - but proof not everything is finished healing.  She said the lump/swelling will eventually go away too.  Just takes time.  Wish I was more patient!  Has your PT shown you scar massage?   That's what gets really tight for me across chest - more  than the arm actually.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 08:52AM JanetinVirginia wrote: In my opinion, the more OUTRAGE about this disease the better.  I think we should all write letters to the editors of major newspapers during "breast cancer month" and try to get more of the truth out there about detection and also finding a CURE.  I'm just got home from hospital from mastectomy yesterday and flipped on news last night.  The first thing I saw was an ABC news segment on a Swedish (I think) study saying that if mammograms began at age 40 many more lives would be saved (or at least extended).  That's one small step in the right direction - but not nearly enough.   What mainstream press never reports is that mammograms miss cancer and that the standard of care ought to be detection through routine ultrasounds & MRIs - starting with women as early as 20 years old!  I had a clear mammogram in March.  Had I known that you can't rely on a mammogram alone, I would have happily paid for routine ultrasound or MRI myself all these years even if insurance didn't.  Then on top of everything else,  they add that 'tests are expensive,' cost/benefit, blah blah blah.  WHAT???   How expensive is lifelong cancer treatment for 200,000 women newly diagnosed EVERY year compared to the cost of an ultrasound or MRI?   Pink ribbons and running races are fine to raise money but I think they also lure the public into believing those women are 'cured'  and 'have a mammogram and everything will be fine.'   It's outrageous and inexcusable in my opinion.  And where is the in-depth reporting on research for the off switch or connecting the dots for a breakthrough cure?

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2011 04:10PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Thanks lago, voracious & others for those links.  I guess the best we can hope for is that a breakthrough will occur before the 5 yr end of tamox, AI & other treatments that can continue to prevent recurrence at that point.  I don't believe the hormonal therapies make you more likely to have a recurrence once you stop the treatment (which some people tend to imply)  -- I think the bounce in stats mean they have just been delaying the onset of a recurrence.  In my opinion, the breast cancer awareness movement carries some responsibility making most people believe that '5 year survival' somehow means you're home free.  I heard an ad for the spring Avon walk & at least their marketing centers around ending this 'deadly disease.'  What keeps me up at night is Dr.Klaus Pantel presentation at San Antonio - that 36% of women with treated early breast cancer and no clinical signs of disease have circulating tumor cells in their bone marrow and that they are different from the original tumor!  I have not seen anyone post on bco that they had a bone marrow test at an early stage - how did they know about all these women!!!?? http://www.knowbreastcancer.org/news-research/news/advocate-reports-from-sabcs-2010.html

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2010 06:13PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Leanna - You're kidding!  Small world!  I went to St Mary's too!! - but only for a year then transferred to TC Williams because it was much closer to home. Yes - best advice is just to keep busy until surgery.  I cleaned my house, froze dinners, did a ton of yard work, etc.  Not only takes your mind off of it, but lets you relax more when you get home because everything is done!  Stock up on a couple of things like some gauze pads, that tape (not adhesive) that doesn't hurt.  Even though I wore a cami, where the drain comes out gets sore.  I found if I taped a fresh gauze pad over it each day (very lightly - you want air to circulate), it didn't get irritated.  There are also some great antibacterial wash cloths that are so soft and you can microwave to make them warm - esp. if your surgeon is like mine and did not want you to shower before first follow-up visit.  You can find them where band-aids are in the drug store (not those handiwipes - these are large).  I just washed my hair in the kitchen sink using the sprayer :)  Also alcohol prep swabs - they are good for wiping off the top of your drain when you handle it to keep it very clean.  Nurses will tell you all this - but it helps to know what you need ahead of time so that someone isn't always running to the drug store for you!
Posts.Title: October 2010 Mastectomy cc4npg cc4npg

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2010 08:04PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Yay!  Welcome home Angelisa!  GREAT news on the nodes.  Yay again!  Mine were clear during surgery & path report confirmed it this week.  Got the drain out too.  So, your recovery will go faster than you think.  I even drove for the first time to the bank today (10 days out).  Still numb under my arm, but surgeon said it takes a while for nerves to get settled down & reconnect. Just take it easy, drink lots of fluids and do your breathing.  When you lie down on your back bend your elbows so your hands are up in the air and make fists 10-15 times.  Just gently - you don't want to stretch anything yet.  That pumps out lymph fluid and will make the hand swelling go down.  That's an Am Cancer Inst exercise.(My hand swelled on the mastectomy side.)  When you are walking around more, the swelling goes down more too.

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2010 09:22PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Angelisa - a GENTLE hug to you!  I didn't have recon, but have read on many posts about the heavy/rubber band feeling w/TEs.  Each day gets better.   I did a couple of errands this morning (driving) and by time I got home I went straight to the sofa for a nap!  All we can do is listen to our bodies.  Short walks are really good for you - that gets circulation going in your arms. Myrrl - did you get one of the those post mastectomy camis?  Those are very soft and have two pockets for drains.  You could ask about more pockets if you're having 4 drains.  But I've heard all kinds of creative ways to cope with drains - lanyards, shoestrings, etc.  You just don't want to accidently tug on them. Otherwise they don't hurt - just very annoying.   Call and speak w/a nurse at your surgeon's office before you go out & spend money to see how the bra situation is handled & what they recommend.  They may send you home w/a compression bra or bandage or whatever. Sometimes they forget to tell you all the details unless you ask.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2010 08:29PM JanetinVirginia wrote: East Coast - yes I need to read up on D2 and D3.  And, yes, I'm post-menopausal.  The first onc (the one I saw again today) wanted to put me on Tamox because it's supposedly easier to take than an AI and better for bones.  That's why he ordered the gene test (cyp2d6).  The second onc said that gnerally post-menop. women should not take Tamox if you still have a uterus (which I do) because of the potential side effect of uterine cancer.  If you have even 2 periods a year that risk is very low (basically goes away) because the lining is still sloughing off.  However, without periods, the lining of the uterus can thicken and then the risk of uterine cancer rises.  You'll probably test out OK because it's only a small minority who can't metabolize it (I was in the lower range).  So , anyway, I got 2 totally different opinions.  Little better now because I would not metabolize Tamox (altho he said it was the back up plan if I couldnt stand the AI).  Going to see the 2nd onc again and then I have to pick a horse & ride it. Ditto on exercise outside & fresh air.   I also read every night in bed until I get sleepy - that way I'm not replaying all the worries of the day right before going to sleep.

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2010 05:10PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Angelisa - I was wondering when you were coming home ! Went to physical therapist today.  She showed me how to stretch the scars so that they will eventually be as soft as skin and not a tight line.  Gave me some other exercises to do for arm.  I haven't been holding the stretch long enough - she said 30 seconds or more for each repetition.  Then she measured both arms in at least 8-10 places.  My left arm (SNL side) is slightly larger.  Because I'm right handed she said right arm should have measured larger.  So there is some edema in left arm - even though no visible swelling :(  The only thing I've noticed is my left hand feels a little tighter.  Told me to put my watch on the other arm (even though it is not a tight fit).   Then went over things I already knew - use bug spray, lots of moisturizer on arm/hand, garden gloves, no BP in that arm or needle sticks, elevate arm and do hand clasps.  Hopefully the edema will resolve by itself over time.  Supposed to go back next week to be re-measured.  She said to continue arm exercises for months, because muscles can contract again.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 09:59PM JanetinVirginia wrote: jp - yes, that's what my breast surgeon (and consult with a PS) told me.  If you decide on a simple mastectomy, reconstruction can be done in the future if you change your mind. meece - yes, I'm glad he insisted on an US.  But, they told me even at 1cm that it had probably been growing for several years.  And, I had yearly mammos religiously which never picked up anything.  Since mine also had 10% DCIS, somewhere during that time it changed from DCIS to IDC.  So now I tell every woman I know to ask about MRIs - not just mammos.  Even if insurance wouldn't cover it, I would gladly have paid for it myself if I had only known that mammos can miss a lot of cancers.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 08:49AM JanetinVirginia wrote: Michelle - I had thyroid papillary cancer when I was 20!!  Now I'm in late 50s!  It is one of the least aggressive & easiest cancers to treat.  I only had surgery and take thyroid replacement pills each day.  There appears to be a genetic link or predisposition - thyroid/breast cancer.  Cleveland Clinic is doing a study and you can get the PTEN test free that checks for that gene (no matter where you live).   If you have a genetic counseling/testing service at your hospital or cancer center, you should ask.  If you do have the gene and have children, they should be monitored more closely for thyroid and avoid Xrays - even at dentist office.  And, EVERYONE - when you do have Xrays, ask for a thyroid guard.  Radiologists never offer that - you have to ask.  It's like a lead collar that protects the thyroid from radiation.

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2011 04:36PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Chrissy - it's a long story.  Last fall, I had a mammo that was "clear" but my gyn felt a thickening in left breast and sent me for US, then an excisional biopsy (which is basically same thing as lumpec) of suspicious spot. That's when I was diagnosed.  Margins were not clear. I had also just had an emergency appendectomy.  I wanted to avoid radiation and no guarantee a 2nd lumpec would be clear.  Since I had to have more surgery anyway I opted for left mastectomy.  I would have done a bilateral but didn't want to push my luck with 3 surgeries w/anesthesia in such short time period and minimize the time I was under (uni vs. BMX).  So I decided to wait 6 mos and then schedule the right prophy - and here I am.  I just do not trust screenings as they didn't pick it up the first time.  And, I may not be so lucky if it came back in the remaining breast.  Altho survival is same for lumpec v. mastec, recurrence rates are lower with mastectomy.  Plus symmetry issues.   I discovered a new trick!  I couldn't tolerate the snug surgical bra - rubbed everywhere.  So the other day I put on a soft T shirt and then the surgical bra on top of that.  Worked like a charm!

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2010 06:07AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 11:51AM by JanetinVirginia No, in my case I did not have a catheter -  I think that depends on how long surgery is supposed to go.  And I think that if you do need one, it's done after you are under - but you might ask that on one of the other forums.  I'm pretty sure my anesthesia was through the IV, but I do remember they had me breathing pure oxygen just before.  Again there are lots of different kinds of anesthesia.  You'll get to see & talk to your surgeon and your anesthesiologist before surgery.  They will go over everything and answer any questions.  I know EXACTLY how you're feeling right now.  All I can say is next week this time it will all be behind you & you will have a huge sense of relief that it's over!  It's nowhere near as bad as I imagined.   Should have saved myself the anxiety:)  Try to stay busy with "to do" lists, go to a movie, take long walks.  All of those things will help take your mind off of it & relax.

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2011 09:38PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Babsbling - call your surgeon's office to ask him/her or the nurse to explain exactly.  Procedures differ so it's hard to tell.  As I understand it, some surgeons do both radioactive injection and a blue dye injection.  Some use one or the other.  In my case, I was injected with the radioactive material and then the technician used a camera-like device to locate the first nodes where your breast lymph system is draining.  That's called the sentinel node (and sometimes more than one).  I was awake for that.  During surgery, while I was asleep, they then injected blue dye which also helps the surgeon locate those nodes to remove and analyze by pathologists while you are still in surgery.  If they are clear, the surgeon doesn't take any more nodes.  If not, the surgeon may take more or all of the nodes under the arm.  (You should ask about that.)  Ask what procedures are planned, if you will be numbed, if you will have a sedative, if you will be awake, or if it will be done while in surgery.  THe more you know, the more prepared you will feel and less scary.  That's the short answer - so have a conversation with the surgeon or nurse and they should go over it in detail with you.  Hope that helps!

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2010 08:57PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Hi sisters.  I'm new to this thread.  I'm stage 1, 0 nodes;100% ER and 98% PR, post menop and somewhere between grade 1 &2 (because two masses).  I posted similar note in 2010 sisters then found the Stage 1 group and thought you may have had this discussion with your oncologists Today was first visit to the Onc. I was expecting her to say with my pathology that I need to take hormone blocker (chemo not indicated).  I was correct on that count - no surprises.  But here is what is completely different. Both the surgeon who did my excisional biopsy and the breast surgeon who did my mastectomy gave me the same recurrence figures when I was making surgery decision.  Survival rate is the same whether you choose lumpec/rads or a mastectomy.  Recurrence somewhat lower in mastectomy (about 1%) than lump/rads (anywhere 5 - 10%).  So, that has been my understanding about recurrence rates.  Today, Onc. said recurrence rate after lump/rads OR mastectomy WITHOUT hormone blocker is 20-30%.  WITH hormone blocker, it would be half or 10-15%.  These recurrence rates seem to be moving targets.  Anybody have a clearer picture?

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 10:19AM JanetinVirginia wrote: Hi boatergirl - did they do an oncotype test?  That will give you some basis.  Depending on your score, it will tell you whether chemo would make any difference, or whether hormone therapy is enough and avoid side effects of chemo.  Sometimes an onc will make the call based on your pathology alone and not do the oncotype test.  The test is not perfect, but does give you more info so you can have a little piece of mind.  Women will good pathology sometimes score high on oncotype and therefore do chemo.  On the other hand, I've read posts where women had low oncotype scores, no chemo & recurrence.  It is definitely overwhelming!  The first onc I saw did not see the need for oncotype test - but the 2nd opinion did.  I'd rather have at least some kind of analysis rather than someone's guess.  (My results were in the low range and no added benefit from chemo.)

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2010 02:50PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Hi Myrrl.  I think you're very smart to do what you're doing! My surgeon said "overnight" is pretty standard altho they can quickly get authorization from insurance if for any reason docs don't feel you're ready to go home.   My insurance authorized 2 nights and more if needed.  Surgeon also said they sign discharge papers early (to show the 23 hrs to save on your hospital costs) but I could hang around all day if I wanted - have lunch, or whatever time was convenient for a ride home, etc.  So they are pretty flexible.  I had left mastectomy (no recon) & went home the next afternoon (my surgery was in the morning).  I only had some nausea the first day and didn't feel like eating, but was up & walking around.  By next morning ate breakfast, lunch ,and was fine.  Did not need any narcotic pain meds - only took regular tylenol now & then altho I would have taken the pain meds in a hearbeat if I needed them.

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2010 01:14AM JanetinVirginia wrote: Eileen - here's how I look at it.  Women decide on prophylatic mastectomy to avoid any cancer and the fact that no other cancer was found I think is the best news you could get.  Look at the very young women in their 20s who choose this as a preventive measure with perfectly healthy breasts.  It may well likely save their lives. Once the cancer is there you have fewer options.  I have pretty much decided that I will have a right prophy in about six months.  I do not want to have to go thru mammos and MRIs every six months, painful biopsies, another SNB, and always worrying.  Hope that helps some.  It's only normal to wonder - but I think you chose the right path.  Don't look back - the future is lookin' bright :) As for the little lightning strikes (I call them) - yes!  But I they have started to go away pretty fast.  I'm a little ahead of you at 3 1/2 weeks.  So it gets better.  It's the nerves healing according to my surgeon.

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2010 02:05PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Hi ladies.  Just back from another follow-up w/b surgeon.  I don't need to see her again until March!  I asked her about my armpit (SNB side) that seems to have a little swelling right in the middle.  When I raise both arms they look different.  She said no that it's actually an optical illusion, because breast tissue was taken out toward the side and just makes it look that way.  I'm actually amazed when she showed me the size of the area that has breast tissue that was removed - starting about 3-4 inches from collar bone and way over to side.  She said at 5 weeks (can't believe how it has flown by now) that little chance of any tearing & now is time to really push the stretching.  (She said not a good idea to be too strenuous much before 3 weeks.)  And - she said it takes 3 months for everything to completely heal.   I have a little bit of scar tissue (about 1" around) underneath skin right where that stupid drain ended (not where it came out of the skin).  She said that should resolve over time & to gently massage it. Glad to hear all the good reports today! Annette - Good that you're off the drugs.  I have seen 3 oncs too and narrowed it down between two of them (didn't like one but liked the other two equally).  I see them both again next week and all my results should be in by then - tamox metabolization, oncotype, etc.  One says tamox, the other says Arimidex.   So I'm hoping for some divine guidance for the best choice.  Oncotype worries me - I read on another thread that the Tailor X trial changed "intermediate" to 11- 25 (instead of 18-32) so that's a big difference.  I'm definitely asking about that next week. myrrl - what a difference a day makes :) angelisa - it's raw & rainy here in the 40s.  I can't seem to get warm today :(

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2010 05:44PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Angelisa - four months is a blip out of your life and the microinvasion doesn't have a chance!  Saw the onc today.  All my results are back in - low Vit D (26); osteoporosis from the Dexa scan; poor metabolizer of Tamoxifen, oncotype 13.  Review of my slides by Georgetown & GW cancer centers indicate a lobular component to my IDC.  He wants me to take 50,000 units Vit D, once a week for 3 months and start Arimidex.  The AIs are hard on bones - so I sure hope the Vit D works.  I posted on the Vit D forum that it sounded like 50,000 was a prescription for a horse !! myrrl - hope you found some pants!  It's amazing how much muscle & tone you lose just from a few weeks of not doing much.  I was stretching out last night and used to be able to get my head almost to my thigh (sitting with legs spread and leaning to each side).  No way.  I need to find a yoga video. I'm going to buy the book "Anticancer: A new way of life by David Servan-Schreiber" for everyone on my Christmas list (and one for moi).  He's an M.D. and a 15 year survivor of brain cancer.   He isn't a nut case, but is convinced life changes in addition to conventional treatments (chemo, rads, adjuvant) is what 'cured' him.  That includes 3 things -- diet, exercise & finding inner peace.  If you go to Amazon and google the title, there is a short video where he is talking.  For example, research shows (and my onc told me this too), women with breast cancer who walk 30 mintues/day six days a week reduce chance of relapse by 50%.  I'm anxious to read it myself - I've read about the anti-cancer diet but haven't read the book.   And, the part about finding inner peace really resonates.  I'm like you Angelisa, I have to tell myself every day to turn it over to God.  But whether it's faith, or a relationship, or losing yourself in things you love to do -- it's so important to turn the corner in terms of stress, anxiety, depression & worry over the stupid cancer.   Those are things we have to find a way to overcome and doesn't come from any treatments or medicines - comes from inside.  Exercise helps -- but I need to find some mental exercises or meditation or something, because it keeps creeping back and I have to smack it down again :):)   Anyone have good tips that work for you?

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2010 07:54AM JanetinVirginia wrote: East Cost - bummer.   But, I wouldn't worry too much about the anesthesia.  There are many kinds and it depends how long they think the surgery will go.  I had an excisional biopsy (which is same as lumpectomy) and later the mastectomy.  When I read the operative report on the lumpectomy (not the pathology report - this is different), I was surprised that it said "sedative and local anesthesia" instead of general.  I think the actual time of the surgery was about 1/2 hour or maybe 45 min.  From my perspective it was a "general" because I was totally out.   So, you might ask about the choices of anesthesia either by calling today or discuss w/anesthesiologist tomorow.   And, I had 3 surgeries right in a row just a few weeks apart (starting with an appendectomy!).  Still, it's not fun, but think of it as a detour.  Prayers & thoughts for tomorrow that this is really minor!!

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2010 12:11AM JanetinVirginia wrote: Found the free scarf links.... http://www.franceluxe.com/pc/L3083B2/headwraps/index.html gailafund.org Angelisa - I guess that makes the decision easier and if I remember they were recommending a short timeframe for you so that's good. PT told me I did not need to come back unless I had some kind of flare up.  I asked her why after getting to a total stretch, the next day I would have to work back up to the stretch.  She said the same thing we've heard from the docs -- when you sleep, that's when all the healing goes on -- so more tissue has knitted together and has to be gently stretched again.  She said that will go on for several more months! I also asked her if I could use my 3 lb weights for arm exercises again - she said nothing heavier than soup cans for now!  (You can lift heavy things at this point (7 weeks) like full grocery bags, etc but not to do repetitive exercises with weights.  So that was interesting. Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2010 10:51PM JanetinVirginia wrote: East Coast & Angelisa - ditto a hundred times over.  In my case it's Arimidex.  The rx is filled and I'm just dragging my feet to get it and start.  I am soooo worried about it for more bone loss, spontaneous fractures, cholesterol & high bp.  I've never had high bp or high cholesterol.  I just don't want to create MORE problems.   At least Tamox protects your bones.  I've never agonized so much over a decision in my life.  I'm going to ask again about ooph again.  Given the choice I'd do the surgery.  But he told me that even though I'm post menopause and ovaries aren't working anyway, I need the AI because estrogen is created by the adrenals somehow and also stored in normal body fat.  So maybe this is another one of those inconsistencies in care.  I just so wish science & medicine were more advanced for better choices.  Just an fyi - both of my cousins had complete hysterectomies in their early 30s - their mother died of ovarian cancer and they have seemed to be fine all these years - they are in their 50s now.   And keep in mind everyone is different - I hardly even knew I was in menopause!  Every now & then I'd kick off the covers at night - but that was it.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2010 05:48PM JanetinVirginia wrote: East Coast - I bought 5 of those books to give to family members for Xmas, including one for myself.  I've read some of it online and have been trying to incorporate many suggestions.  (I'm eating cruciferous veggies like there is no tomorrow - broccoli, brussel sprouts.) Have gone totally organic for dairy, meats, poultry and most fruits/veggies.  Whole grains in terms of cereal bread (I'm with you on no white rolls/breads).  At least 1/2 hour/day of exercise.  Some of this I already did, but trying to focus more.  I have no clue about the cosmetics & soy so I need to read up on that so I can watch labels. Does the anticancer book cover that?  I also want to lose 10 lbs even though I don't really need to.  But they say the less fat, the less estrogen. I'm going to give Arimidex a try, but that drug really scares me and doubt I'll do 5 years.  Eileen - I got the Amoena (want to call it amoeba!) essential.  I can't find any store that carries Silique, but would like to see those.   Doesn't it make you crazy that you can't confer with doctor about adult children!! There is no 18 year old equipped to deal with the complexities of healthcare. This HIPPA stuff is ridiculous. I think there are new forms now that people can give 'permission' for a parent to be involved.  Angelisa - it's a constant battle to beat back the 'darkness' - and to know it will be hovering rest of my life is truly upsetting.  I just try to think about the POSITIVE odds of not having a recurrence and not the negative odds of recurrence and do the things that help in that direction (diet, exercise, etc). I'm kind of achey on the mastectomy side today for some reason, so guess the healing process continues on....

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 01:14AM JanetinVirginia wrote: Cathie - glad you found us!  Wecome to our little team!  My stats similar too.  I had left mastectomy and 99% sure I will have right prophy this spring.  I would have had bi-lateral to begin with, but within matter of few weeks had just had an appendectomy, followed by excisional biopsy under a general and didn't want to push my luck with the 3rd surgery.  So I just decided to do the left first.  I was concerned enough just before Christmas to have a mammo & US on the right because I felt another thickening.  But nothing showed up on either (BIRADS 0) altho the tech could feel what I meant.  That pretty much decided it for me - I don't want to have to go through these tests every 6 mos rest of my life!  I know lots of women feel differently, but I'm all for mastectomy as it takes chance of local recurrence to near zero, and also reduces distant recurrence at least through nodes.  Have my script for Tamox - seeing my pcp and gyn this week for some last tests to be as ready as I can.  Had some issues when I started Arimidex so Tamox better be OK!! East Coast - yes Eileen (I think it was Eileen) was right when she posted some time ago that the stress really comes way after the surgery. I think some of that is going on with me in being so tentative to start the hormone therapy.  It's like I expect the worst of anything now after being blindsided w/bc. Angelisa - good luck on the insurance issues getting in place for your daughter.  And wonderful news you can say you're almost DONE with treatment.  Hope you haven't had anymore fast heartbeat episodes. Myrrl - when does spring semester start? Hopefully you have a few more weeks to rest.  I think my son's classes start back around the 20th - which means tuition is due soon:( Annette - how are you doing?  I saw you checked in few days ago!  It is a pain trying to pace blood tests in one arm.  I had one last week and the tech left a HUGE bruise.  Was supposed to get another one (diff. doc) and decided to wait a few days.  I don't want to wear it out. Girls, I have a GOOD feeling about 2011!!   It's going to be a year of breakthroughs in cancer treatment.  Already one announced today - a new revolutionary blood test.  Was on ABC evening news tonight.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 09:21PM JanetinVirginia wrote: I'm with the other girls myrrl.  Your body will tell you when you;re feeling up to it.  You've been through a LOT.  When I talked to BS office about getting prophy scheduled, she said since the screenings were clear she'd prefer at least 6 mos between surgeries - so that puts me sometime in March - probably near end as she is on vacation in the middle and doesn't want to do the surgery and then leave town:)   Anyway, my point is your body can only take so much - so if there isn't any urgency better to pace yourself. Got full cardiology workup after the chest pains w/Arimidex - EKG, echocardiogram, and stress test.  Doc said no problem w/blood flow and it wasn't due to cardiac function - could have been the meds or could have been a teeny piece of plaque that decided to break off.  So - who knows.  I still think it was Arimidex.  Not having issues so far anyway w/Tamox.  He asked what my LDL was and of course I couldn't remember- should have called my PCP.  He said if thats in high middle or borderline (100 -160) then a statin is a good idea.  He said there is a clinical trial going on now - because there is some indication that statins also reduce breast cancer recurrence as well as cardiac events!  (Remember that's the LDL level  or bad cholesterol, not total cholesterol level.) That's all for now.  Hope everyone doing OK.

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2010 02:28PM JanetinVirginia wrote: Michelekb - I see by the date of your post your surgery is over. How did you do?  If anyone else is worrying about this, give yourself peace of mind and call your insurance company (usually number on back of your card).  My insurance authorized 2 days and longer if needed/directed by admitting doc.  I didn't have reconstruction so my surgery was shorter starting 10:30a,.  My surgeon had told I would have discharge papers the next morning but not to feel like I had to leave first thing in the morning - could hang around that day as long as I wanted.  She also said I would not be discharged unless I was totally stable (BP, incision, etc.).  I was very nauseas/sick that night but by morning was eating breakfast, etc.  I ended up wanting to go home mid afternoon the next day.  I worried about only staying one night too because only my son lives at home.  So I had arranged a visitng nurse the day after I went home just to check on me.  Turns out I didn't need it at all.  Worrying about the surgery was much worse than the surgery.
